reviewText: Jumping in to place my first review in defense of a game that seems to get a lot of grief for the randomness of the gameplay. It's RNG. Accept it. One bad roll can destroy you; that's the risk. But when you gamble on a long shot and win, it feels so rewarding. Couple that with the strategy of chosing where to deploy your people, when to activate their abilities, managing the ship's modules, and deciding what rolls to reasolve problems with and which to bank for new abilities, this simple RNG becomes quite a fun challenge where the right choices can hold off disaster just long enough to turn everything around---of course the next bad roll may doom you anyway, but it's still fun! Games are quick,too. Maybe 30 to 40 minutes to beat it, with several unlockable characters to keep you coming back. And apaprently new missions are in the works. I watched several youtubers play the game before decding to buy it, and when I found myself talking to the screen, telling the player he should've rolled another character's dice or chose a diffenent ability, it became clear I just needed to try it for myself (I grabbed it with the intro discount, so it was $10, which feels reasonable to a new release of this style). The story is blagh, but that doesn't affect the gameplay. Bottomline, if you enjoy tabletop dice games like Zombie Dice and accept the fact that chance is a factor, this is a fun little time-killer.

reviewText:
Should you get this game?

First lets cull the dice haters. There are dice in this game. They are very important - that is - bad results can topple the best strategies. If that makes your blood boil don't get this game.

If your dislike of dice is more nuanced  then they are probably ok here. People who are on the fence about dice usually don't like them when they are a fail or succeed mechanism (like D&D), but like them when they give options (like Yahtzee). While there are better and worse rolls here, most rolls can be played in a number of different and (to me) interesting ways.

So - if you make it past the Dice check you will fall into one of the following three cases:

Case 1) I have played cooperative board games and like them (Pandemic, Ghost Story, Forbidden Island, Flash Point - there are dozens of these).

You will almost certainly love this. It solidly in that genre, yet with clean original mechanics. It plays fast with a wide variety of situations, and has a lot of skill. For the players that feel it is too hard - it might be, but these games want to be a real accomplishment when you beat them otherwise they tend to be used up once you understand them. There will be games that you can't win - but many of the best solitaire games are that way - and you just try to get the best record you can. (I would be curious what a really good win % is, knowing that can often mitigate the immediate reaction the game is too hard)

Case 2) I have played cooperative board games and don't like them.

There is still a small chance that you will like this. If you don't like them because you don't like other people arguing with you about the best strategy, and dealing with tons of fiddly bits - you might like this because the computer handles the fiddly bits and doesn't argue with you. If that doesn't describe you then this game will hold no interest for you.

Case 3) Cooperative board game, whAaa?

If you haven't played a cooperative board game it is hard to predict whether or not you will like this. It is very much a computer board game, this could easily be turned into a non virtual game. It is turned based, has a lot of luck and a lot of skill, and it plays fast. It is probably different than any game you have played before. A brief description of the genre: Bad stuff happens every turn. You deploy your team every turn to put out fires and prevent future disasters as best you can. In this game survive 10 turns in the ♥♥♥♥ storm that is released upon you and you win.

reviewText:
This game has crushing unfair difficulty, and that's precisely what the developers intended. Winning isn't impossible, but it requires careful strategy and lots of sacrifice because you will never fix all the problems every turn. The trick is ensuring that you don't lose anything critical and carefully judging the odds to put yourself in the best position. Even with optimum strategy you will still usually lose but you are on a suicide mission so that's expected.

What I like most about the game is the deep strategy involved where you have to think deeply about every move.

The game has a fair few problems with it. It is very lacking in content and I was unpleasently suprised to reach mars and get nothing but a short vague cutscene that explained nothing and was less involved than even the earlier ones. I do think that an easy difficulty should have been included not doing so is simply being elitest. Hopefully these issues will be corrected in the future as the game is still in early access.

reviewText:
Tharsis is a very short game, that has you control a crew of astronauts on their journey to Mars. Halfway through a meteroid shower critically damages the ship, destroying all your storages and killing two of your crew. Now you have to survive for ten weeks (= turns) until you reach your destination, constantly busy repairing old and new damage, trying to improve your food stock and ship health, and keeping as many as possible alive.

Cool? It's a game based on rolling dies, with random events each turn, where all you can do is to manage and deploy your crew to improve your odds as good as possible. You do that by keeping the number of dies available to each crew member as high as possible (requiring food), by keeping them from getting injured and their stress levels low, by fixing up the hull - and by having as many asissts (protection against unfortunate die values) available as possible. Unfortunately all that requires die which you also need to constantly repair the damage poping up all around the ship. And then there's the research tab that allows you to store up to six die and invest them later to repair a module, add asissts or improve health/stress.

Managing this - crew, their abilities, deploying them in the right order and to the most sensible modules, keeping them effective and healthy, and using your dies as efficient as possible - that's the challenge of this game. Yes, it's heavily randomized, and even the best tactics can't save you from disaster if Lady Luck doesn't smile on you, but trying is fun too. As it's only ten turns (each taking about a minute or so) long, you can try often, using different crew compositions (you unlock new crew members by meeting certain challenges) and tactics.

It's a short, challenging but fun time waster. If you can cope with the randomness, and the above sounds good for you, then give it a try: you'll probably be very positively surprised.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game, as it's an interesting mix of both a video game and a board game. Your basic goal is to survive 10 turns of disasters, panic and dice till your team makes it to Mars. However there is a very strange twist to the story as the two of the six crewmembers die in a massive micro-meteor strike. The story only gets stranger the closer you get to mars, giving it that very eerie feel, something which only grows stronger with the ending.

Though the game has a significant element of luck in the dice, it is the epitome of requiring lateral thinking to fixing problems that one faces as well as absolute micromanagement of resources. It is difficult. it is harsh. But it is rewarding. So very rewarding when you plan things right and you can tank through the damage to your ship to land all four crew on mars.

The art style is a great blend of the old classics such as 2001: A Space Odyssey and the Black Hole, while still making it look all so functional like the more recent Martian movie. It's fun to look at, the music is entrancing and it's the small details from the dice that turn into bloodied messes if your crew have eaten human flesh to the description of the events and systems that just pulls it all together.

It's small playtime of 20-30 minutes of each run give it a very FTL feel, while the procedural generated nature means you really cannot predict what might happen next turn or if the dice go south. It's interesting, it's fascinating and unique. I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves board games, space and the desperate panic that comes with trying to survive.

reviewText:
Harder than a teenager about to lose his virginity, and every bit as tense.

EDIT - 21st January:

Given how long I've spent playing Tharsis, and how much I enjoyed doing so, I figured it deserved a better review from me than a single sentence attempt at being funny.

Ultimately, I found the gameplay experience sufficiently compelling that I kept returning to Tharsis until I unlocked all of the achievements and crew members, and will enthusiastically go back to the game when the developers release the upcoming missions promised on the menu screen. I don't think there's anything more that anyone could reasonably expect from Tharsis, ergo it comes with my strong recommendation to anyone who is intrigued by the disaster in space premise, and who is happy to embrace the dice-based approach to keeping the Iktomi spacecraft - and it's crew - intact.

Regarding the infamous difficulty, my play record is 45 attempts, with 10 successful arrivals at Mars. Additionally, I would say that 5-10 of my failures were due to obvious errors on my part, and so overall I don't personally believe my win rate to be unfair or unacceptable... especially when you take into account that the basic scenario of the game would hardly be a simple one to overcome were it to ever happen in real life. There IS a lot of random chance, of course - such is the way when dice are involved - but at the same time there are generally multiple options available to the player at any one time, with many of them allowing him or her to take something from even low numbered rolls... even simply utilising an otherwise useless dice to shake up the reseach choices can reveal an option which, when subsequently taken, helps to get the player on top of their situation.

I've seen others compare Tharsis to FTL, given that they both offer an uncompromising challenge in a cosmic setting. Having played FTL myself, and failing to complete it even once, I can say that title triggered a lot more irritation than Tharsis ever did... for me, the fact that the final battle in FTL is one where the big boss comes back several times, even though it's more than tough enough to just make it that far in the first place and beat one iteration of the last enemy, perfectly encompasses how unfair - and occasionally rage-inducing - that game can feel. To my mind, FTL leaves the player fewer options for making the best of bad luck, and with the absence of dice - i.e. random chance - feels a lot more deliberately, and downright spitefully, difficult for difficulty's sake... as a consequence, it alienated me in a manner that Tharsis never did.

All that said, I've not tried Tharsis on the hard difficulty setting, and don't have any intention of doing so... normal mode is more than enough of a challenge for me!

I'm not going to claim that I think the game is perfect, however... I do personally believe that some crew members (e.g. the doctor and the mechanic) are a lot more useful than others (although this would quite possibly be the case in the aftermath of any real-life space accident en route to Mars), but then it could also be argued that getting the less helpful astronauts to their destination simply represents another gameplay vector for those who wish to replay the title in order to chase achievements. Plus, for all that I've generally stuck up for the challenge that Tharsis offers, nevertheless even I sometimes feel that the game has it in for the player on some attempts, for instance when it throws several modules with 2-3 damage - and 2-3 injury and/or void dice - at you on consecutive turns, which can be practically impossible to survive even with the most serendipitous of dice rolls. Also, the ending of the game is somewhat 'out there', and perhaps a little unsatisfying overall, although I admit that I liked the playful nod to its entertainment medium (if I've interpreted things correctly, that is).

reviewText:
This is basically a space board game, with interesting and overlapping systems.  I've watched streams and played enough to where I have a good feel of how the game works, and it's a lot about balancing risks.  Every turn you ponder for a few minutes, thinking of who to send where, and who can do what.

A typical turn might look like this:
Alright, I have three things to fix this turn, and two of them will blow up the ship.  My mechanic's at one of them, a broken hatch.  He needs to roll 19 with five dice to fix it, which is doable but tricky.  He'll probably need help.  My doctor's in a room with another event, but he only has two health, and there's a chance of injury here.  If he tries to fix it alone he might die.  I could leave it alone--lose one health on my doctor, run him to the more ship critical SPDA damage in med bay.  If I get lucky I could use the medbay to patch up my doctor as well.  That leaves the captain and pilot with three dice each.  I'll the captain to medbay first, use my accumulated research to give him another die, and send the pilot to help the mechanic.

Once you have a plan, you begin execution, rolling the dice, adapting the plan to what happens.  Sometimes the dice fall in your favor--the mechanic might get lucky and fix the hatch all by himself--that frees up my pilot to help with the medbay.  Maybe he rolls poorly--I cycle the dice into research, shuffling and hoping for ship hull fixes or a quick repair.  If it doesn't work maybe I use his skill to give me just one more hull point to survive until the next turn.

If you're into games that require this sort of planning, execution, adaptation, combined with desperation and unflinching difficulty, then this game is for you.  The game will try to blow up your ship and kill your crew at every turn, but through careful planning and estimation of risks, you can overcome those odds, guide your crew through a very narrow path and eventually, survive.  And immediately after succeeding, all you'll want to do is try again.

--

A note on randomness--I've read a lot of reviews about how much luck is involved in the game.  It is true that if you always roll exactly what you need, you'll win, and the game is easy.  Most of the game is not around this however--it's about managing the situation so that it's likely you get what you need, and figuring out how to scramble in the cases you don't.

This game is hard. It's brutal. I don't see myself replaying it dozens of times, but one playthrough was enough for me. I was so determined to beat this game that I ended up staying up til 4am the night I bought it-- only to die and not beat it until a week later.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game. I think partly because I enjoy boardgames and this plays very much like a solo board game. Graphically it is nothing that special, it looks pretty static, I only learned later on by chance that some parts of the scenery are animated if you click on them. The game play is hard, deliberately so. At first you might be thinking isn't there an easier mode, but part of the enjoyment comes from the fact you will learn strategies that get you a little further each time.

Okay luck plays a big part as well, it is dice based after all, sometimes even you best strategy will fail because of a bad roll, or some damage occurs that you just aren't ready to deal with, but that's part of the fun/frustration as well. Your strategies just help stack the odds in your favour, but sometimes the fates just aren't with you. I've only had the game crash on me once, but I didn't lose any progress, and they are still patching the game at the moment.

When you do beat the game there is a real sense of achievement. I'm not sure how much replay value is there once you do manage to get to Mars, so far I've completed it once. This game certainly isn't going to appeal to everyone, but it's clear a lot of thought went into the design and it really captures the themes they were aiming for. If you like dice based boardgames, then you may enjoy this.

I found tharsis, while watching a streamer on youtube playing it, and saw that it was my kind of game, I read many of the reviews of the game, blaming its shortcomings on difficulty and seeming unfairness. I'm happy to see that missions seems to be coming out soonish, as i have finished the game, on both normal + hard in total of 4 attempts. aka, its a short game if you know how to manipulate dice well.

One thing i will cede, is that the difficulty of normal and hard are not too far apart, there definately could be an easy setting for new people/streamers who just wish to get through the game. I would make this a new setting, seeing as, if it got just a little bit easier, then most every playthrough would be won, as currently, facing problems head on will just barely kill you (albeit everytime) on normal difficulty

reviewText:
Tharsis is quite in interesting game about dice, cannibalism, and teaching metaphysical aliens what it means to be human.
While the game seems hard at the first glance, after a couple of playthrough you come to realise how you're supposed to play. The only two problems I really have are:
-The lack of contents, but with the price it actually is I won't list it as a negative thing.
-The ending (spoiler alert: it makes sense, but I think they hid the actually meaning way too deep inside the story to be easily understood).
If you don't want to be spoiled, don't read further.
Explanation about the story:
So Tharsis is set in the same universe as Laserlife, a game about a dead astronaut found floating in space by an extremely advanced alien lifeform who doesn't completely exist as a physical being. The dead astronaut is in fact the one who gets ejected into space in the beginning of Tharsis.
At the end of Laserlife, the alien understand the hardship and the sacrifices the humans endured, and since Tharsis also feature a metaphysical alien at the end (with one ending ending with the sentence The anomaly... It knew".)

reviewText:
Luck of the roll is the key to winning this game yet the dice seem to have a mind of its own. Meaning you can't rely on luck to win. The game seems to punish you for even thinking you can get humans to Mars. I can't say I hated the game yet it did make my brain hurt.

Seemingly everything is random throughout the game. Starting health conditions of characters, hunger levels, where system damage takes place, dangerous pitfall condition when attempting to repair. Using the special abilities of Astronauts is crucial if you wish to survive. Each pod also has bonuses which can help a player if he/she takes advantage of it. (even in lew of repairing systems)

The brief cut scenes between repairs tell a story which ends in a cool sci-fi paradox yet the story telling gives too much information throughout the game which lessens the climatic ending.

All and all I liked the game. If I have any grips it would be I wish the game had more character to unlock.  btw I finally made it to Mars with my entire grew. Eat that NASA!

reviewText:
Now this game was a real surprise! Tharsis blends an interesting boardgame aesthetic with the tough decision-making and resource-management of the best in turn-based strategy sims. At first it seems as if the dice completely control the experience, but as you spend more time with the game it becomes apparent that the real strategy comes from learning *when* to move, *who* to move, *where* to move and what to repair when you get there, always taking into account that low dice rolls may throw a wrench into your plans. The secret is to plan your turns in such a way that you minimize the severity of low dice rolls, and celebrate the moments when the dice are kind. It's really a one-in-a-kind experience.

And that's not to mention the temptation of making use of *all* the possible meals on board as the mission progresses... once you see the possibility of eking one more week of survival by making costly sacrifices, it becomes very difficult to stop...

Highly recommended.

reviewText: Tharsis is a survival strategy game, played in bite-sized short sessions with a good meta-progression. It's a perfect storm of deep, rewarding strategy and the thrill of the dice. A lot. But instead of feeling bad about a defeat, you'll feel excited to try something new.

reviewText:
I saw this and it really looked intriguing.  Then I read the reviews.  Even the people who really liked it complained about how hard it was!  Since I like this sort of game, I hesitantly gave it a try, but was prepared to be frustrated.

Well, I beat it on normal on my first shot, with no crew deaths, and no one left behind.  It's not actually that hard.  The game really gives you a lot of tools to mitigate unlucky rolls.  Yes, you could just pull all of the worst events and have your ship destroyed, but it isn't very likely.  Edit - I am now 2 for 2 on normal.

If you like board games, and you can handle randomness, then you will like this game.  Risk management in this game really reminds me of risk management in Blood Bowl.  Unlucky things can and will happen, but you can mitigate them by playing smart.

If randomness frustrates you, or you don't like turn based strategy games, or board game like games, then you'll hate this.

If you play it and think it's too hard because it's too random, then you may want to re-evaluate how good you are at risk management.

reviewText: Watch my video review here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N22Nm4xXDew\n\nThe objective: get to Mars. The crew must scramble each turn to repair rooms and counteract ship damage and other negative events. Each room can provide different bonuses, from food production to ship repair and health increases. Each crew member has a class that determines their special ability, health, stress level (higher stress makes for worse decision choices), and dice supply (replenished with food). Dice are rolled in each repair event, used to simply repair the calamity, activate the crew member’s class ability or room module ability, or undertake research projects for instant benefits. Each repair mission can have hazards that will cause crew damage, locked dice, or lost dice if specific numbers are rolled; hazards can be automatically countered with assists. Tharsis excels in crisis prioritization: there are never enough crew to do everything, and placing the right combination of crew in the right rooms in the right order produces intriguing strategy. An interesting setting and compelling strategy makes Tharsis a distinctive, albeit very challenging, survival game.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game, as it's an interesting mix of both a video game and a board game. Your basic goal is to survive 10 turns of disasters, panic and dice till your team makes it to Mars. However there is a very strange twist to the story as the two of the six crewmembers die in a massive micro-meteor strike. The story only gets stranger the closer you get to mars, giving it that very eerie feel, something which only grows stronger with the ending.

Though the game has a significant element of luck in the dice, it is the epitome of requiring lateral thinking to fixing problems that one faces as well as absolute micromanagement of resources. It is difficult. it is harsh. But it is rewarding. So very rewarding when you plan things right and you can tank through the damage to your ship to land all four crew on mars.

The art style is a great blend of the old classics such as 2001: A Space Odyssey and the Black Hole, while still making it look all so functional like the more recent Martian movie. It's fun to look at, the music is entrancing and it's the small details from the dice that turn into bloodied messes if your crew have eaten human flesh to the description of the events and systems that just pulls it all together.

It's small playtime of 20-30 minutes of each run give it a very FTL feel, while the procedural generated nature means you really cannot predict what might happen next turn or if the dice go south. It's interesting, it's fascinating and unique. I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves board games, space and the desperate panic that comes with trying to survive.

reviewText:
Harder than a teenager about to lose his virginity, and every bit as tense.

EDIT - 21st January:

Given how long I've spent playing Tharsis, and how much I enjoyed doing so, I figured it deserved a better review from me than a single sentence attempt at being funny.

Ultimately, I found the gameplay experience sufficiently compelling that I kept returning to Tharsis until I unlocked all of the achievements and crew members, and will enthusiastically go back to the game when the developers release the upcoming missions promised on the menu screen. I don't think there's anything more that anyone could reasonably expect from Tharsis, ergo it comes with my strong recommendation to anyone who is intrigued by the disaster in space premise, and who is happy to embrace the dice-based approach to keeping the Iktomi spacecraft - and it's crew - intact.

Regarding the infamous difficulty, my play record is 45 attempts, with 10 successful arrivals at Mars. Additionally, I would say that 5-10 of my failures were due to obvious errors on my part, and so overall I don't personally believe my win rate to be unfair or unacceptable... especially when you take into account that the basic scenario of the game would hardly be a simple one to overcome were it to ever happen in real life. There IS a lot of random chance, of course - such is the way when dice are involved - but at the same time there are generally multiple options available to the player at any one time, with many of them allowing him or her to take something from even low numbered rolls... even simply utilising an otherwise useless dice to shake up the reseach choices can reveal an option which, when subsequently taken, helps to get the player on top of their situation.

I've seen others compare Tharsis to FTL, given that they both offer an uncompromising challenge in a cosmic setting. Having played FTL myself, and failing to complete it even once, I can say that title triggered a lot more irritation than Tharsis ever did... for me, the fact that the final battle in FTL is one where the big boss comes back several times, even though it's more than tough enough to just make it that far in the first place and beat one iteration of the last enemy, perfectly encompasses how unfair - and occasionally rage-inducing - that game can feel. To my mind, FTL leaves the player fewer options for making the best of bad luck, and with the absence of dice - i.e. random chance - feels a lot more deliberately, and downright spitefully, difficult for difficulty's sake... as a consequence, it alienated me in a manner that Tharsis never did.

All that said, I've not tried Tharsis on the hard difficulty setting, and don't have any intention of doing so... normal mode is more than enough of a challenge for me!

I'm not going to claim that I think the game is perfect, however... I do personally believe that some crew members (e.g. the doctor and the mechanic) are a lot more useful than others (although this would quite possibly be the case in the aftermath of any real-life space accident en route to Mars), but then it could also be argued that getting the less helpful astronauts to their destination simply represents another gameplay vector for those who wish to replay the title in order to chase achievements. Plus, for all that I've generally stuck up for the challenge that Tharsis offers, nevertheless even I sometimes feel that the game has it in for the player on some attempts, for instance when it throws several modules with 2-3 damage - and 2-3 injury and/or void dice - at you on consecutive turns, which can be practically impossible to survive even with the most serendipitous of dice rolls. Also, the ending of the game is somewhat 'out there', and perhaps a little unsatisfying overall, although I admit that I liked the playful nod to its entertainment medium (if I've interpreted things correctly, that is).

reviewText:
This is basically a space board game, with interesting and overlapping systems.  I've watched streams and played enough to where I have a good feel of how the game works, and it's a lot about balancing risks.  Every turn you ponder for a few minutes, thinking of who to send where, and who can do what.

A typical turn might look like this:
Alright, I have three things to fix this turn, and two of them will blow up the ship.  My mechanic's at one of them, a broken hatch.  He needs to roll 19 with five dice to fix it, which is doable but tricky.  He'll probably need help.  My doctor's in a room with another event, but he only has two health, and there's a chance of injury here.  If he tries to fix it alone he might die.  I could leave it alone--lose one health on my doctor, run him to the more ship critical SPDA damage in med bay.  If I get lucky I could use the medbay to patch up my doctor as well.  That leaves the captain and pilot with three dice each.  I'll the captain to medbay first, use my accumulated research to give him another die, and send the pilot to help the mechanic.

Once you have a plan, you begin execution, rolling the dice, adapting the plan to what happens.  Sometimes the dice fall in your favor--the mechanic might get lucky and fix the hatch all by himself--that frees up my pilot to help with the medbay.  Maybe he rolls poorly--I cycle the dice into research, shuffling and hoping for ship hull fixes or a quick repair.  If it doesn't work maybe I use his skill to give me just one more hull point to survive until the next turn.

If you're into games that require this sort of planning, execution, adaptation, combined with desperation and unflinching difficulty, then this game is for you.  The game will try to blow up your ship and kill your crew at every turn, but through careful planning and estimation of risks, you can overcome those odds, guide your crew through a very narrow path and eventually, survive.  And immediately after succeeding, all you'll want to do is try again.

--

A note on randomness--I've read a lot of reviews about how much luck is involved in the game.  It is true that if you always roll exactly what you need, you'll win, and the game is easy.  Most of the game is not around this however--it's about managing the situation so that it's likely you get what you need, and figuring out how to scramble in the cases you don't.

reviewText:
I have to say, the ways you can be humiliated and punished BY DICES in this game are extremely broad. You will cry. You will argue. You will become the black hole made of butthurt. Than, you will win and prevail.

Actually, there are things that could be made better about the game, and setting aside the balance (if the game is hard on purpose, its not a balance problem, but of attitude) -- things like crew deaths (whice are death sentence except if they happen in last 2 rounds) -- could be made more enjoyable, more appealing for storytelling. I mean, developers definitely try to do that by compensating you with cannibalism perks and stuff, but in 23 games played I have yet to see the situation when it helps enough to survive. Maybe there should be different compensation, i don't know.
Stories like 'and than my guy goes in the room and rolls 3 double injuries, but I found the way to make his charred remains into anti-stress gym equipment' are more funnier than '... and of course i lost the run'.

In other things, the game is pretty smart, you need to pay attention. For example, you roll 1+2, dices get stasis, you can't reroll and you could waste them making only 3 repairs OR you could use the science and make them into 7-repair spell. Also, you have to plan ahead and split '=' dices in food and repair rooms between guys.

Anyway, buy this only if you are not scared to lose much. Or wait till they do missions and stuff.

reviewText:
Don't listen to the haters telling you this game is too hard. I beat it on my first try with all crew members surviving (well, actually 3 because I chose to have the captain go down with the ship effecting last minute repairs, but I could have just had him bypass that section because everyone had enough health) and the ship was at max hull, and I had more food than I knew what to do with. I will try hard mode now and see if its any different.

Honestly, you just have to be good at math and understand the order in which to do things and what's worth more to you. Obviously there is a component of luck, because yes the starting conditions are random and the sections that get damaged are random too, but its not like I had to restart 5 times to get a good setup, I had a winning setup on my first try.

As for the game, great graphics, beautiful sounds, really nice gameplay, polished, definitely a finished product. Its a short game, but you'd hate it if it was any longer. Probably a bit pricey in terms of dollars/hours of gameplay, but I'm not sorry I got it.

Definitely recommend if you don't mind a thinking game where you have to carefully weigh choices and plan things out (and then leave it all in the hands of fate, lol).

reviewText:
This is a super fun game.

It is super challenging at first. That's a good thing! This makes it that much more rewarding when you finally figure out how to play it.

To the people claiming it is unwinnable due to RNG, you are just not playing with the right strategy. Anyone interested in playing this game I recommend trying a few times on your own, then checking out the twitch stream of the guy who (at time of writing this) has a 22 GAME WIN STREAK. He explains why he makes all his choices and you see how they play out.

The biggest two tips I can offer are don't focus on fixing all events every turn and keep your dice as high as posisble. You can replenish dice through food, captain ability, modules, research projects, or side projects. Use them all. There are so many ways to do so that RNG is no excuse.

Bonus, since it is turn based I can play this while at work during down time!

reviewText:
Well, would I reccommend Tharsis?  The anwser is yes.

Would I add a warning to the game? The answer is yes.

If you want an entertaining game to relax, have fun and relieve sone stress this one might not be for you.

If you enjoy a challenge and like to be the underdog in a battle trying to succeed against heavy odds.. this is definitely for you!!

If I had to describe Tharsis in one word it would be...  Brutal.

It gives you no quarter, there is no easy way to keep the crew alive and get them safely to Mars.

Be prepared to say goodbye to one crew member after another as they perish in the deadly almost futile attempt to reach the red planet.

But back to the original question,  would I reccommend this game to any gamer who wants a real challenge?

The answer of course is YES!!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you:

- Don't mind RNG destroying you.
- Like boardgames or any kind of dice RNG game.
- Enjoy trying to win against almost insurmountable odds.
- Want every choice to be life or death.
- Don't mind eating people.

...then you'll probably like Tharsis.  If any of the above turns you off, then you probably won't.

The game has a good overall design to it.  There isn't so much to it that it becomes unwieldy, but there's not so little that decisions are easy A, B, or C decisions.  There's decent room for strategy without complexity turning this into a min/max playground.  You live or die on luck here, and it's as simple as that.

It took me 9 hours to get to the end of the journey, with an average game time of around 20 minutes or so, I think.  I was able to adopt strategies that increased my odds over the journey, but it still all comes down to luck.  Had I not gotten certain throws during my winning game, it would have easily been a loss.

I recommend this game because it delivers on what it claims to be.  I enjoyed my time with it, and I've paid a lot more for games that have given me 10 hours of time.  Whether you believe it's worth the entry price is up to you, but I think it's fair.

reviewText:
TLDR: Very difficult survival management game using dice rolls to determine success/failure. Good game once you get the hang of it, but don't expect to win many games. (so far i've played 9 games and haven't won one yet - record is 3 weeks from mars)

Long version:
So you're on a space ship going to mars, and suddenly your ship is falling apart. You have 4 crew members onboard and your ship has an overall hull strength". Each module of the ship has an ability you can use
date: and each crew member has an ability you can use. Each round
recommended: 2-3 modules on your ship breaks and you need to either repair them or suffer the consequences. At the end of each round you are given a choice between 2-3 options which usually is getting something good and accepting something bad.\n\nSo
hoursPlayed: what are you managing?\n1. You need to harvest food to keep your crew fed (each time you use a crew member
voteText:
he loses one dice. One food regains 3 dice)
2. You need to repair ship modules to keep using their abilities and to prevent their side effects (ie: a broken module can cause damage to hull strength or affect crew health)
3. You need to increase crew health when possible
4. You need to decrease crew stress when possible
5. You need to increase hull strength when possible

There is only a few downsides to this game at the moment. First is that it isn't well explained in some areas. For example
helpfulPercent: when you see 3 empty boxes with equal signs between them
votesHelpful: it means you need to put up to 3 dice with the same number in the boxes. The boxes will fill up left to right
votesTotal: and the diamonds below the boxes indicate how many of the reward you will recieve for filling that box in.\n\nSecond
votesFunny: I find the "Normal" mode to be very difficult. I'd love an "easy mode" while learning the game
commentsCount: where your crew starts off being fully fed (5 dice) and you get only 2 damage events per "round"\n\n"

reviewText:
Now this game was a real surprise! Tharsis blends an interesting boardgame aesthetic with the tough decision-making and resource-management of the best in turn-based strategy sims. At first it seems as if the dice completely control the experience, but as you spend more time with the game it becomes apparent that the real strategy comes from learning *when* to move, *who* to move, *where* to move and what to repair when you get there, always taking into account that low dice rolls may throw a wrench into your plans. The secret is to plan your turns in such a way that you minimize the severity of low dice rolls, and celebrate the moments when the dice are kind. It's really a one-in-a-kind experience.

And that's not to mention the temptation of making use of *all* the possible meals on board as the mission progresses... once you see the possibility of eking one more week of survival by making costly sacrifices, it becomes very difficult to stop...

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
EDITED after 19 hours of gameplay, original version below

Win ratio: 7/19 ~37% if not going for achivements I think 45-55% is perfectly achiveable with the crew suited for the strategy used. Perfectly achievable by me of course. Some will do worse and other better.

This game gets so many negative reviews mostly because people just fail to realize what their options are.

One does not simply win Tharsis by moving crew and clicking Roll (unless we take infinite monkey theorem[en.wikipedia.org] into consideration, then this statement would be obviously false). There is a lot, and I mean A LOT, of strategy behind it. You just need to make an effort to learn to see it or simply accept that it's not for you, refund and forget.

==========

Original review after 2 hours of gameplay

I beat the game on the second try but lets call this luck. In fact, just like FTL, Tharsis is all about three things:
1. risk management
2. making right choices when given (if given at all)
3. using your crew skills

A little bit of math can do wonders and often helps to avoid total disasters. Of course not all playthroughs can or even should be beatable so if you cannot stand this then Tharsis is not for you.

Small hint: remember that avarage score from rolling a 6-sided die is not 3 - it's 3.5 - this helps alot while making crucial decisions.

reviewText: Brutally difficult.  This is a game about risk management and optimization. Don't expect to win half the time.  Expect to win one in five if you learn fast, maybe.  This game is fun if you are willing to learn and can get past the fact that the dice personally offended you by not turning up a 5 when you wanted one.

reviewText:
Harder than a teenager about to lose his virginity, and every bit as tense.

EDIT - 21st January:

Given how long I've spent playing Tharsis, and how much I enjoyed doing so, I figured it deserved a better review from me than a single sentence attempt at being funny.

Ultimately, I found the gameplay experience sufficiently compelling that I kept returning to Tharsis until I unlocked all of the achievements and crew members, and will enthusiastically go back to the game when the developers release the upcoming missions promised on the menu screen. I don't think there's anything more that anyone could reasonably expect from Tharsis, ergo it comes with my strong recommendation to anyone who is intrigued by the disaster in space premise, and who is happy to embrace the dice-based approach to keeping the Iktomi spacecraft - and it's crew - intact.

Regarding the infamous difficulty, my play record is 45 attempts, with 10 successful arrivals at Mars. Additionally, I would say that 5-10 of my failures were due to obvious errors on my part, and so overall I don't personally believe my win rate to be unfair or unacceptable... especially when you take into account that the basic scenario of the game would hardly be a simple one to overcome were it to ever happen in real life. There IS a lot of random chance, of course - such is the way when dice are involved - but at the same time there are generally multiple options available to the player at any one time, with many of them allowing him or her to take something from even low numbered rolls... even simply utilising an otherwise useless dice to shake up the reseach choices can reveal an option which, when subsequently taken, helps to get the player on top of their situation.

I've seen others compare Tharsis to FTL, given that they both offer an uncompromising challenge in a cosmic setting. Having played FTL myself, and failing to complete it even once, I can say that title triggered a lot more irritation than Tharsis ever did... for me, the fact that the final battle in FTL is one where the big boss comes back several times, even though it's more than tough enough to just make it that far in the first place and beat one iteration of the last enemy, perfectly encompasses how unfair - and occasionally rage-inducing - that game can feel. To my mind, FTL leaves the player fewer options for making the best of bad luck, and with the absence of dice - i.e. random chance - feels a lot more deliberately, and downright spitefully, difficult for difficulty's sake... as a consequence, it alienated me in a manner that Tharsis never did.

All that said, I've not tried Tharsis on the hard difficulty setting, and don't have any intention of doing so... normal mode is more than enough of a challenge for me!

I'm not going to claim that I think the game is perfect, however... I do personally believe that some crew members (e.g. the doctor and the mechanic) are a lot more useful than others (although this would quite possibly be the case in the aftermath of any real-life space accident en route to Mars), but then it could also be argued that getting the less helpful astronauts to their destination simply represents another gameplay vector for those who wish to replay the title in order to chase achievements. Plus, for all that I've generally stuck up for the challenge that Tharsis offers, nevertheless even I sometimes feel that the game has it in for the player on some attempts, for instance when it throws several modules with 2-3 damage - and 2-3 injury and/or void dice - at you on consecutive turns, which can be practically impossible to survive even with the most serendipitous of dice rolls. Also, the ending of the game is somewhat 'out there', and perhaps a little unsatisfying overall, although I admit that I liked the playful nod to its entertainment medium (if I've interpreted things correctly, that is).

reviewText: Yes: it's difficult. Yes: there's a lot of randomness and unwinnable situations. You will get your nose (and your dice) bloodied. You can make all the right decisions and still lose.\n\nHowever, the only way to win at this game is to have both luck AND skill. When you win, you'll know that it wasn't just blind luck that handed you victory. You made the tough choices. You managed every resource well, even your own sanity. You pressed your luck. You knew the odds and you did it anyway, and it worked. You ate them. YOU HAD TO. But you made it.

reviewText:
You roll some dice. You fix that pesky SSU undervolt. You engage in some light cannibalism. You roll some more dice. You put out a fire in your hydroponics bay. More cannibalism. Then a micrometeorite storm ruptures the hull, killing everybody on your ship. You sigh, and start the whole grisly business again from the top.

If you enjoy torturing yourself with games that put you entirely at the mercy of random number generators, then there's plenty of sweet torture to be had here. A typical playthrough isn't that long, so it isn't too frustrating if you get screwed over by a couple of bad dice rolls.

Oh, and I wasn't joking about the cannibalism. The first time I successfully completed the game, I only did so by strategically killing one of my crew members, and having the surviving crew feast on the remains.

reviewText: Alright, went into the game knowing it was brutal. It should be more like BRUTAL. I think I did about 10 runs or so. Out of the 10 runs I made it past the 3/4s mark (week 6/7) most of the time. I only beat the game once. The 1 time I did beat it I got 4 achievements. One for nobody dieing, one for not consuming any flesh, one for reaching Mars, and one for not taking any damage hull damager for 4 turns. So, yes this game is hard but that's the beauty of it. Youre in a spaceship and the crew has the worst luck imaginable. If this game was any easier it wouldn't be enjoyable. This game challenges you. It makes you pick the best of the worst things that can happen. It makes you actually manage. Forces you to pay attention to what you are doing.\n\nSo, with everything said I should point out that sure I lost 9 times and only wont once. That 1 win was memorable and highly enjoying though. I can't wait to unlock the other astronauts and try out the other planned content.

reviewText:
It's an interesting game but it needs some balancing. You have about as much chance of getting through this as winning a game of Solitaire, which after 2 hours of trying, this is what it felt like.

Yes I would recomend it but be prepare to be frustrated. Most games for me lasted anywhere from 2 to 4 weeks (A week is a level) with an average of about 3... out of what seems to be a 8 weeks/levels game...

Say you are left with 3 guys with 3 dice each and you are hit with 3 events that would require 2 guys with 6 dice each to complete... it's certainly auto death. the game should be more aware of the number of dice left and balance the events accordingly

The dice system is cool but the MAJOR anoyance is no having the choice to bypass the assist/counteract. it auto-conteract and you dont have a say in when and for what it's applied. Say the hazard is 1 dye Injury the other Stasis and your character has 3 health and you roll 3 injury dye and one stasis I wouls us the contract on the injury... I wouls also often not conteract stasis or void if the rest of the dice, or even the locked dice have what I want because I would really like the conteract to no be used because the next event would require it more,

If they add the choice on the what the assist conteracts I think it would likely balance the game and make it more strategy than pure mindless random solitaire type game...

reviewText: This is a white-knuckle turn based dice game that will frustrate and entertain you.  I'd liken the feeling of success in this game to when you defeat a boss in a Soulsborne game.  Despite the calm of it’s turn based approach the tension with every choice is so high that it makes every success elating and every failure crushing.  Fortunately you can jump in and start a new game quickly and learn from your past mistakes.  If you want to sit at your keyboard and press the space bar till your computer says “You Win” I wouldn’t recommend this game for you.

reviewText:
A fantastic game.

Yes, it is a game that relies on the throw of a dice, therefore, obviously, there will be a very huge random element.

However, there are a lot of options and opportunities to mitigate the negative impact of a bad dice throw.
Make use of your assists and research options!

Having your crew die horribly and your ship break apart is part of the experience.

I've made it to mars in my third try. Now on to hard difficulty...
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has crushing unfair difficulty, and that's precisely what the developers intended. Winning isn't impossible, but it requires careful strategy and lots of sacrifice because you will never fix all the problems every turn. The trick is ensuring that you don't lose anything critical and carefully judging the odds to put yourself in the best position. Even with optimum strategy you will still usually lose but you are on a suicide mission so that's expected.

What I like most about the game is the deep strategy involved where you have to think deeply about every move.

The game has a fair few problems with it. It is very lacking in content and I was unpleasently suprised to reach mars and get nothing but a short vague cutscene that explained nothing and was less involved than even the earlier ones. I do think that an easy difficulty should have been included not doing so is simply being elitest. Hopefully these issues will be corrected in the future as the game is still in early access.

reviewText:
TLDR: Very difficult survival management game using dice rolls to determine success/failure. Good game once you get the hang of it, but don't expect to win many games. (so far i've played 9 games and haven't won one yet - record is 3 weeks from mars)

Long version:
So you're on a space ship going to mars, and suddenly your ship is falling apart. You have 4 crew members onboard and your ship has an overall hull strength". Each module of the ship has an ability you can use
date: and each crew member has an ability you can use. Each round
recommended: 2-3 modules on your ship breaks and you need to either repair them or suffer the consequences. At the end of each round you are given a choice between 2-3 options which usually is getting something good and accepting something bad.\n\nSo
hoursPlayed: what are you managing?\n1. You need to harvest food to keep your crew fed (each time you use a crew member
voteText:
he loses one dice. One food regains 3 dice)
2. You need to repair ship modules to keep using their abilities and to prevent their side effects (ie: a broken module can cause damage to hull strength or affect crew health)
3. You need to increase crew health when possible
4. You need to decrease crew stress when possible
5. You need to increase hull strength when possible

There is only a few downsides to this game at the moment. First is that it isn't well explained in some areas. For example

reviewText: I'm loving this game and if you love exquisitely difficult board games like Arkham Horror or Pandemic then I think you'll dig it too. reviewText:
Repairing your ship armed only with dice, and occasionally eating a crew member... THAT'S THARSIS BABY!

First off, this is NOT Yahtzee.  You roll dice, and someitmes need a double or two, that is where the similarity stops.

Secondly, it is a HARD game.  Even on the normal mode.  But it is not impossible, unfair, or out of the player's hands if they win or not.  EVERY choice you make goes a long way to landing on Mars.  Think before you roll.  Set yourself up to farm health, food, ship HP, or whatever you think you will need going forward.  Then tackle those events that are most threatening to you first.  Have a plan.  Use the Captain  & Doctor in the right modules, and in the right order, to benefit from their specialties.  And always have assists!  (And use them productively when you have them!)

Now with the warnings & tips out of the way... let's touch on the review part of this review!

Tharsis is very much a tactical dice game where you have to balance repairing the ship (using the value of the dice you roll) while managing your crew & ship HP, harvesting food, and other tasks during a run.

It is RNG/luck based in the sense that you cannot control what you roll on the dice, but you can put yourself in a better position to succeed if you roll more dice, avoid injuries by banking assists, and utilizing crew & module specialties to stockpile more HP, dice, assists, and more.

Each event will spawn with some “hazard” dice.  These hazards consist of dice you cannot reroll (Stasis).  Dice that hurt you if you match he posted number (Injury).  And even dice that vanish from the playing field (Void).  This adds to the amount of strategy you have to consider in the game because not only do you have to get rid of these events (they stack up!), you have to manage in what order, and with which crew member you will tackle them with!

This game is addictive, frustrating, and is always pushing me to get better at it.  I cannot wait to play some more, or see what future updates have in store for us!

reviewText:
Trying to take some time to review every new game I play on Steam in 2016.

- Tharsis's story is not interesting or satisfying. Not atrocious, but adds little to the game itself.
+ I'm not the first person to say this, but there is something interesting in that the dice based gameplay means you're never truly in control of the chaos.
- However, it too often feels that the your success or failure is decided early on, and the remaining turns are just ancilary.
+ The sights, sounds, and music work well together to create a good atmosphere.
+ I like space.

reviewText:
I really, really like Tharsis. It's unforgiving as all hell and really makes you think about the decisions you need to make for the crew in order to try and survive. I still have yet to beat it but I keep getting closer and closer. I have no doubt that I'll make it pretty soon.

If you're looking for a challenge, I recommend picking it up.

--------------------

After playing the game for about 3 hours I've finally managd to beat it with 3 crew members still alive. I did have to cannibalize one of the crew but still, I made it.

I really liked the game and the challenge in managing all of the events. The story is intriguing but I wish there was more of it. Each game can start to feel a bit stale when the same events keep happening from game to game since in the beginning you tend to restart pretty often.

I know missions aren’t in yet which will likely help but I’m not feeling a strong compulsion to play again just yet. With varying events and more content in general I'm sure this will change. I'll definitely try and unlock the rest of the characters at some point because it will help mix things up a bit.

That said, I still definitely recommend picking it up if you're a fan of board games. It's a fun game that will only get better as future updates are released.

reviewText:
Glorified Sci-Fi Yahtzee

I'm a huge fan of rogue-lite games. I'm also keen on challenges. This game is neither.

You have little-to-no control over the game's outcomes. Sure, you can mitigate a point of damage here and there through crew movement. You might be able to turn the tide of one week by choosing to invest a die in research rather than a module ability. But with every action, you're at the complete mercy of the dice--both literally, with the D6 system that resembles Yahtzee more than it does the D&D system the devs claim inspired them. And you're also subject to getting shorted with the random events generator...which dishes out four or more random fates per turn. (2-3 module damage events per round, all of which have their failed void" "injury" and "stasis"mechanics; plus a "choose your own turd sandwich" event at the end of the round.)

The game looks good
recommended: but it turns out to be nothing more than Yahtzee with a bit more complex rules..."

reviewText:
As if being stranded in space wasn't bad enough, you have to deal with a constant shower of meteorites (on the way from Earth to Mars, WTF? is it a bunch of troll aliens shooting NERF guns from behind the moon?) that damage your ship modules every turn and you need to fix that.
Oh and of course the game starts by destroying your food supplies so in a matter of hours your whole crew turns cannibal and starts eating fallen comrades (you can choose to not eat your friends, but that's basically a death sentence for everyone).
Anyway, you read reviews of this game, you know it's going to be crushing hard and you like dice so you think you're up for a challenge. After all, you finished Dark Souls so how hard could it be?
Well...don't take it personally but no amount of skill, preparation or resilience will help you.
Only luck will.
Just toss a coin right now, heads or tails, you actually have better odds.
Your crew of trained astronauts will strive to fix damaged modules with the amazing power of dice, that in my opinion are totally jacked to make you roll crap, and when you think you got everything under control, the game will reming you very clearly that you are not in the next turn.
I put Not recommended" because I am not a fan of games when the difficulty is unfair and no matter how many times you play or train the outcome will only be decided by luck
date: this is just like gambling in a slot machine
recommended: and the payout isn't that good."

reviewText:
This could be an amazing multiplayer board game. However, without multiplayer the game has limited replay value which could be an issue since the games are <30mins.

- Fun mechanics

Cons:

- Token storyline

reviewText:
Despite a refreshing game mechanic, with new and ingenious levels of strategy, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend this game.
Simply put, for a game that dramatically relies on your actions and successes to progress, there is no actual correlation between how well you perform (or how lucky you get) to how well the story is going. To elaborate, events will happen in the story regardless of how well you do in a level.
<spoiler>At an earlier point, my food stores were near full, but the story cutscene still said that we are low on supplies. Then at another point, one of my crew members was just killed, but the cutscene tells me that the crew is trying to reassure me that I'm being paranoid about being a poor leader (maybe I just understood it that way). <end spoiler>
Perhaps if my actions affected the story more than simply advancing it, then I would recommend this game.
Then there is the story itself, which ends in a very anti-climactic way.
<spoiler>This wouldn't be so bad, but you literally see the end coming two cutscenes before the actual ending <end spoilers>.
Still, I had fun playing the game, and if it made any difference to play it multiple times storywise, I would totally still be playing it. But I was able to finish the game after 3 tries (each attempt lasting around 20 to thirty minutes), and the achievements and extra characters are not really that enticing.
So in the end, this game will kick your ♥♥♥, and kick it hard. But the pay off is so small, all that pain and frustration really isn't worth it.

tells you in no uncertain terms that you no longer have any chance at all of winning. What masochist would keep playing under such circumstances?

Obviously the single incentive to keep spending time with this evil little slot machine is the hope that drives any gambler: "Maybe this time!" That's it.

Fair enough. But when the main draw of a game is the endless drudgery of trying and failing again and again

reviewText:
I can't in good conscience recommend this title.

The premise is great, this has the right ingredients to be a really enjoyable game.
*BUT*... You're entirely at the whims of RNG.
The initial story is quite interesting and suggests there is atleast some mystery to be solved.
And I did read there are multiple endings to reach - though I don't know the extent of that.
On top of that there are plans for future content to be added overtime.

All of that is good.
However if you have to go through a dozen failed runs. Not because you made a mistake.
But because the game just outright decided to mess you up with random events and poor dicerolls?

It starts off when your characters get their dice given to them. This alone can really mess you up.
Having the wrong character with low dice? Forget that first turn.
Then comes number two, which is the random events. Sometimes you get events that you can essentially ignore because their damage" is inconsequential (a SYSFAIL on a system you wouldn't use for example).
Other times you simply get a chain of damage ship
date:
damage crew and lose dice events one after another.
Making losing out on any one of them immediately a lost run.

Even if you get past that
recommended: then you have the hazard dice. Getting "stasis" dice is probably your best bet
hoursPlayed: though can lock you down for solving the challenge. Getting two or even three "injury" dice and a single bad roll can outright kill a character. Getting a few void dice can simply make it so you can not resolve an event meaning it stick around and next turn you get two or three MORE events on top.\n\nThe "assist" function seems to work from left to right as the hazard dice are displayed. So say you have one assist
voteText:
and both a stasis AND an injury dice (in that order). Then the stasis gets assisted and your character will get hit.
You can't even plan around it and put the assists on hazards of your choosing.

If you like RNG? Then this is for you
helpfulPercent: because if there is one thing Tharsis excels at its putting RNG into its RNG to RNG its RNG.\nI hope you're a follower of RNGeesus

If you like dice games you'll have fun with this one! It feels very much like a table-top dice game with lots of choices to make and nuanced strategy to engage. reviewText:
I just want to say this is a good dice game.

It does have a lot of strategy elements with which you can significantly better your chances and manage your crises more effectively.
For example i have seen the complaint that you can't really use your Specialist" with the "+1 to rerolls" because all the "Stasis" results lock your dice. I most often just stock up on "Assists" so i have can use her first and more effectively because she can still use all her dice afer the potential horrible first dice throw.

Also

reviewText:
The only thing which outperforms the really nice balancing in this game, is the games incredible ability to attract the wrong players.

Although you are rolling dice in this game, your job is not to use the dice to solve your problems - but to use your brains to restrain the dice's evil spirits. Tharsis is can be beaten pretty consistently and is only RNG-dependant for those who decide to rely on the RNG (and therefore are doomed). But don't be fooled it might not come easy for you.

I really recommend if you're into solitaire strategy games, but 15€ might be a bit too high, as there is not soo much content.

reviewText:
At this point I cannot recommend Tharsis. It is an incomplete product that shows promise of a great game, but does not yet deliver. I will update my review if this changes.

Tharsis is a dice game, which brings a certain kind of randomness into the game play. Now many games provide dice mitigation and manipulation to stabilize the game play, Tharsis doesn't. Instead it opts for a more poker-like approach where a single roll is not really relevant, your overall strategy is (i.e. you might loose some battles, but you still strife to win the war).

This would be fine, as long as the challenges were generated in a controlled manner. Unfortunately they are not. The game has no issue with generating unbeatable" challenges for you

recommended: meaning it will one-shot pretty much anyone attempting the challenge and "black hole" -- high number with a 4
voteText: 6 void dice.\n\nApart from this
helpfulPercent: game UI needs some small tweaks and the game overall needs more content for its price (but that is apparently coming).\n\nI do believe that if some of the game mechanics were tweaked and made more transparent
votesHelpful: the game would become a great casual time-waster of mine
votesTotal: but right now
votesFunny: I will go back to my board game collection instead."

reviewText:
I'm not one to normally review a game, but I feel like this one is getting a bad rap.  It's hard, but it's only as hard as you make it.  You've really got to think and consider every move, and maybe you'll get lucky.

I've played through three times, and I've already finished once.  The dice are part of it, but using the dice is the biggest deal.  Don't neglect research, assists = life, and see if you can free up a crewmember to get some food.  Consider the chances, and realize that the odds are neither in your favor nor against you, they just are.  Don't expect to roll all sixes, but if you're smart, every dice will be useful.

The beauty of this game is the fact that it makes you think about what you're going to do and have a plan.  And then have another three plans behind that, if the first one fails.  If you play like that, you've got a better chance.  Everything is a resource, a trade-off.  If you've got four dice, statistics would say that you've got an even chance of fixing 14 repair.  If it's above that number, expect to have two crew work it.  Beef up the ship if you can't make the full fix, and get it next turn.  Use the resources you have to cover those you don't.

This is a thinking game, and one that will still tell you no, even if you come up with the best plan.  But, if you take your time, consider, question, and try, you'll make it happen.  I think it's an excellent game, and one that I will go back and play again, and die many times in the process.

reviewText:
Tharsis brings a breath of fresh air to rouge like games. Most rouge likes are random and frustrating because it seems like wether you put 10 seconds or 10 minutes into a decsion it doesn't matter; Tharsis rewards players for thinking out all decsions, you can play it safe or take a risk and the game changes drasticlly depending on how safe you wanna play it. Each time I play it is a new hell of dying crew and a ship that is falling apart, making it so each new game I don't just have the same strategy over and over again. The music amazing and sets a theme for the game, and this the only game where I actually feel remorse over letting my crew die or cannabilizing their corpses, the crew's animations change as more bad things happen around them, and actually seeing them start to lose it really connects you to the crew. All in all it is a game the lets new players have fun diying, and allows good players to be good and feel good about mastering the game. Amazing game that will occupy me for many many hours.


TLDR- If you are remotly interested in strategy or rouge likes, buy this. Fun for noobs and Hardcores alike.

reviewText:
I beat the game after ~5 runs. I found it to be a very interesting game, because of how the dice rolls are used in the ship's systems. Sadly, I find that the outcome of the game almost ENTIRELY depends on the rolls that you get. There is a certain amount of strategy in regards to what you can let roll over to the next turn, who will need to take a few damage/lose dice, and which systems to use. Some rolls would perfectly fix a module in one attempt. Others would instantly kill that crew member. This is nothing short of infuriating when you consider how difficult the game is.

RNG aside, I enjoyed the design of the game's systems, the overall aestehtic, and the way the game keeps the common story of a mission to Mars fresh.

The game also has a great artstyle and an amazing soundtrack.

If you can enjoy the game even though the dice will attempt to ruin you at every moment, you should play it.

reviewText:
This is a great game, and I think it deserves better than a mixed rating.

Pros:
- Great gameplay.  The game makes you feel like all of your decisions are important and impactful, and you usually have multiple options available to you at any point.  Strategic planning and risk management feel important, and there are enough ways to mitigate RNG that it doesn't feel too random.
- Each run takes about an hour, so it's great to play casually.  You can have a satisfying game in a short time.  You feel accomplished when you've beaten everything the game throws at you.
- Great art direction.  The ship feels both retro and vaguely plausible near-future tech at the same time.  The music is pretty good and reminds me of Radiohead in places.  There's a real sense of desperation in the storytelling and tone of the game.
- Could be fun to play with friends?  I could definitely see having a laugh at tabletop night with this.

Cons:
- Only one main scenario/objective in the game currently.  The core gameplay is very fun and well designed, but the amount of variety might be too limited for some players.  The abilities on some crew aren't super exciting to use from a decision-making standpoint.
- The conclusion to the story is open-ended and some players may dislike this.
- The level of challenge is very high.  Even playing optimally, you might not win every time.  I feel like this adds an enjoyable amount of tension to the game, but players that dislike a good challenge or hate losing will disagree.

I think the value equation of this game is good.  You're probably playing for at least 10 hours to unlock the majority of the crew, and the game costs about the same as other survival-based board games I've purchased.

People are complaining about RNG, but YOU control where your crew deploy, what level of risk you assume, and where you invest your dice.  Think about the odds before you do something.  The game gives you many tools to manage risk and plan strategically, but you need to use those tools.

The level of luck in this game is similar to Poker.  There is some luck involved, but it's mostly a skill-based game, and it is possible to win consistently using the same strategies.  This is not a game where you can just yolo" and hope for the best.  Use your brain!"

For those complaining that this game is impossible, I landed all 4 crew members on Mars on my very first play through on Normal. My crews stress was high, their health was low, my ship was held together with duct tape and 2 of my capsules were malfunctioning, but I got them all into the landing pod and made it to the surface. Hard mode will probably kill me, but this game is possible. It will be a frustrating experience to be sure, but that makes victory all the more gratifying.

reviewText:
Hmm, a good game, it is very dificult to win, so know that going in.

You only need to survive 10 turns to win but losing on turn 4-6 has been my average. The game is heavily dice based so random chance can easily hamstring any sort of strategy you had in mind, which occasionally makes losing feel too random. My main complaint is that even after 10 games each playthrough still feels too similar. Nothing different enough happens to change your playstyle. So I feel as though I'm left trying the same things over and over again hoping that the dice eventually roll more favorably. Since you can't really 'bank' enough alternative options you're often left at the mercy of random chance. I love what the game is trying to do with the dice but it needs a bit more tweaking to give the player a little more agency in how things playout.

There are some unlockable crew memebrs that might mix things up a bit but I haven't gotten anywhere near unlocking them. So another 4-6 hours of playing might give me the chance to play with those characters.

It's a well made game so I still give it a positive review, but I have mixed feelings, so read more reviews to see if it's really the kind of game that would bring you fun.

reviewText:
This game seems to have no effort on play balance. It is stacked against the player. Brutal is the correct word for it. I can't recommend any game like that because it is just not fun. Simple changes like writing code to examine the die roll restrictions vs the target number and balancing that would allow the game to become fun. Then you could exercise choice like sending a spare crew member to a special module to try and gain its benefits.

Because of the poor game balance I ended up immediately not caring about the story at all, pressing space bar to skip it, only to watch in amazement at the next turn's cascading series of disasters which end up mathematically impossible.

Everything else is great: concept, mechanics, graphics, music and story. What a shame; what a waste of a potentially good game. Do not buy this game unless it gets patched to improve playability.

reviewText:
This game is literally impossible. Like, it’s not “challenging” it is un-beatable.
As you start out every resource you have is at half. All four crew half health or worse, 2 food (under half) 3 or fewer dice on any crew member and one assist. Now, food I can understand being low as the McGuffins for the game is the pantry blew up so you have no food and things are bad ok. Maybe also a crewmember or two is injured but there is no reason the whole crew is so near death. Did they send the up into space with anemia and dysentery?!?
And I can’t shake the feeling that the crew is suicidal. After the first turn…successfully putting out all the fires and radiation leaks, I get to make a crew choice that is never helpful. You’d think that they’d be hyped up by the team work they just pulled but no…it just feels so bad. I did good, I beat the stiff rolls and managed not to take any hits on my ship, then I get rewarded with crippling crew choices. Sucks. If I left 4 of 7 modules with hazards id expect to have more tough choices just seems unfairly antagonistic.

reviewText:
Read the reviews, and despite my better judgement of wanting to stay away due to so many negative reviews complaining about how unfair the system is I ended up buying this title. Will be refunding it.

Anyway, in short there are so many negative things that can happen during a turn that (SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED TO HAPPEN) it literally can make it impossible to not die or not die the following turn.
Literally due to the fact taht you can get 1) Bad rolls 2) 3 negative effects to impair your rolls for 1 event 3) Multiple events instead of just 2 during a turn 4) All events dealing damage to ship (could even have 2 events doing 2 damage to ship) 5) High repair rolls needed for an event.  ALL of these can happen in one turn and can literally turn your perfect game of full health, low stress, high dice count, no one dead, and half repaired ship into a loss.

Now there are character I have no unlocked and could possibly change my opinion on the game but due to the fact many people complain about 15 to 20 games before winning once I am cashing in now with a refund so I won't risk feeling cheated even after unlocking those characters.

reviewText:
Highly RNG-based game. Strategizing is pretty irrelevant compared to what Research modules you get, and where the damage on your ship happens. For example, if the Greenhouse is damaged, you can easily obtain extra food on that turn, which makes the game a cakewalk. Likewise, if you get the Research modules which repair your ship, you can easily bypass high-injury risk and use the repair module instead; but if you only get Dice modules you could easily lose just based off of that.

Being able to cannibalize is cute, but you only want to do it if you are already losing due to bad RNG, and it's often just a band-aid solution and you will eventually lose anyway from the bad start.

It's fun for an hour or so, but I would not recommend buying it for more than $5.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. The premise is highy inviting, especially for those of us who are board gamers first. When playing a single player game, a person should have more control over the outcome of their session. From the very start of every run, you are completely at the whim of the random event engine. If you half your ship suffers from food blight, then you'll possibly be able to seal your crew into the engine room and coast until you hit Mars; otherwise, you're eventually going to come to a point where a winning scenario is mathematically impossible. And it's not because of anything you did, it's just the random nature of the game.

If this were the Kobayashi Maru, this review would be different but that's not what this is being billed as. Here's my suggestion; go onto your roof and balance a board out over the edge. weight down the end on the roof with approximately 30 medium-sized sleeping cats. Now go out onto the edge of the board and play yahtzee. Maybe enough of the cats will stay napping on the board that you won't fall off or maybe they'll bugger off tipping you into the abyss. Either way, it wasn't anything you did which kept those cats either staying put or scattering like an exploding hornet nest, so you can't be mad at it. However, you can be disappointed.

If this scenario sounds like an interesting way to spend an afternoon, then by all means, buy this game. If this scenario sounds like madness, maybe you should think twice about buying this game.
