reviewText:
Guys. Hey, guys.

If you have any doubts about this game because of the raging fearmongers who tell you it's impossible and that its RNG is broken, bla bla bla...

Please, look at my profile. Look at my Achievz for this game:

Got to Mars
Most of Crew Intact (Captain went down with the ship)
Didn't Eat Anyone
IN 3.2 HOURS

Let me explain exactly what's going on here.

Tharsis has a VERY steep learning curve at the beginning. You're scrambling to put out 800 fires at once, and you only have enough energy to put out... 2 of them. The game forces you to squash immediate threats to your survival while you scramble to create even the slightest semblance of long-term stability. It also forces you to be verrrrry meticulous about the placement of crew, the use of modules (different locations aboard the ship), and the distribution of dice.

As the developers explained in one of their videos, you shouldn't be fooled by the apparent arbitrary nature of the dice... No, you don't get to choose what numbers come up, but you DO get to choose how to apply them, and that makes ALL the difference in the world. If you're using the right character in the right ship module, or choosing the right research option, what may look like a handful of lousy rolls can easily be turned around into game-changing effects that're even more powerful than straight rolling against the target numbers of various emergency tasks that you have to deal with. Examples:

* If you're in the Maintenance Bay, a pair of snake eyes can counter crippling damage elsewhere on the ship while someone else is whittling away at those repairs.

*If you're in the Laboratory, you can reset the ship's Assist which blocks hazardous dice rolls, protecting the rest of your crew from lethal injuries while they work elsewhere on the ship.

YES, YOU WILL FAIL! MULTIPLE TIMES! Don't be discouraged. I think my first 3 playthroughs lasted a combined total of about 15 minutes... When you still don't know what you're doing, getting smoked takes minimal effort and it happens in the blink of an eye. It may be 5 games, 10 games, before your experience starts to feel more like progress and less like surprise buttsekz, but the good news is that those first few rounds will probably fly by too quickly for you to dwell on them. And slowly, steadily, you'll get further and further along on your voyage.

All of your crew members have unique abilities, and there are different ways to play with each of them, and other unique crew that unlock after various achievements... and then the sheer randomness of the game itself, as well as a higher difficulty, all add up to a fair amount of replayability for the truly masochistic. Apparently they also have additional Missions" of an undisclosed nature coming down the pipe as well

reviewText: Tharsis is one of the most frustrating games I've ever played!  While the idea of surviving in space sounds cool, it's overshadowed by the game's numerous problems.  The tutorial does a poor job in explaining the rules of the game, causing players to feel lost and confused without looking up the Help Option.  The RNG system works against the player, from events piling on you right in the beginning of the game to making unfair choices inbetween turns.  It's not worth it's asking price, especially when there's no extra features in a game that can be beaten in 1 to 2 hrs if you're lucky enough.\n\nRating: D-

reviewText: This is the first time I've requested a refund on a game through Steam. There's potential in this game, but as it stands now the deck is too firmly stacked against the player. It's supposed to be difficult, yes, but not mathematically impossible 90 percent of the time. As others have written, the problem is one of balance. There are too few turns and far, far too many events per turn, even in the middle stages of the game, for the player to have even a hope of managing the situation. It turns what should be an exciting, challenging game of resource management and risk into an utterly hopeless endeavor.\n\nIt should be hard, and it is. It should force you to make incredibly difficult choices, and it does. It should not, however, render each and every one of those choices moot by the imbalances currently present in the game.

reviewText:
Great Idea. Bad execution.
If this were a real board game, it would be broken.

Watch the designers' videos. It's interesting that the lead designer goes on ad nauseum about his design inspirations, because he succeeded in ship design, and failed horribly in character design. I find it painful to watch the character animations. (Also, the music is absolute torture.)
In the systems designer's video, he references King of Tokyo and Craps (of all things) as justification for the use of actual dice in this simulated board game. Great, dude; so why didn't you bother to study more appropriate game models when working out your mechanics? Games such as Elder SIgn, Alea Iacta Est, Yspahan, Arkham Horror, or Pandemic?

Here's the thing with a game like this: There has to be some inkling of hope for success. It is definitely important to keep this kind of game challenging, but this game in particular suffers from balance issues (which is a shame - read on).
In bg design, we have an ongoing debate about the win:loss ratio of this kind of game, and its effect on replayability. On average, the consensus among designers is that the players should win one in five to ten plays in order to avoid frustration and want to ever again take the box off the shelf.
This game sets you up to fail regardless of any concern for your experience beyond the mere process of playing. It's not challenging; it's rigged.

I've played ten times now, and from the very first turn of every game, I  never  had any hope that I would succeed. I'll probably sit down one more night and play through another ten times, just to get a better idea of the trends, but here's where I think the design is fundamentally flawed: Initial setup and escalation curve.
The odds are too steep coming out of the gate, and there are never adequate opportunities to prepare for the next challenge(s). I understand the need to keep the pressure on the player, so I don't lament the lack of opportunity to get ahead or on top of the progression, but the most consistent experience I have at the beginning of every round of Tharsis is that there's no point to try to continue the game. It is obviously hopeless at every turn. This is a critical failure in the area of balancing.

Designers, you have to let the players have some hope! In all but one of my playthroughs, I looked at the (obviously random and arbitrary) dice allocations at the start of game, and felt there was no point to even beginning the game. Did you even playtest this thing, or did you just write some automated script to crunch the numbers? You clearly put a lot of thought into the process, but failed to adequately consider the experience. (A common failing among bg designers.)

Ultimately, I think the  concept  of Tharsis is delightful, and the  process  of Tharsis is fun - I really enjoy the dice allocation mechanic, the hard decisions, and the thematic challenges.
But the game is broken in setup and balance: FIx that, and Tharss would be an excellent game.

reviewText:
It doesn't take too long to know that this game won't be fun. There's the initial aesthetic of playing a challenging game with a learning curve that takes some getting used to. It reminded me a little bit of Dark Souls in that respect. But unlike Dark Souls, there's no chance for improvement. In fact, it is only chance that dictates how well you will do in this game. I played maybe 10 games and while that might not seem like much, it was enough to tell me that I would not enjoy the game. There was no light at the end of the tunnel. Apparently, the game acts like somewhat of a god that will pity you at some point and allow you to win easily, but there is little payoff, at least for now. The Missions option that isn't finished yet could breathe some life into the game, but I doubt it. Like my Mars inbound crew, the game is cold and dead.

Tl;dr
You won't win unless the game wants you to. That's not fun.

reviewText:
This game has potential. A lot of potential... But it needs a lot of balancing before it gets there. Randomised dice rolls that you have to prioritise and manage make for a very interesting game and very fun. The character perks add a decent amount of customisation to the game as well. Story is engaging, and the visuals are pretty good for a relativley simple setup.

However, the random 'encounters' if you will, realy need to be tweaked. Having 3 events that remove 2 health each and require 20+ points to address is an instant restart. Or else watch your crewmen die in 1, maybe 2 turns.

This game is fun enough to play, just dont expect any real progression until it has been balanced a lot more.
Also- cut scenes are not skipable with the mouse. Mildly annoying, but dealable.

Good game to get on sale at the moment. Otherwise... eh.

reviewText:
It wants to be like a hard rogue-like, like FTL, but misses the mark.

The basics are this:

Each turn random events affect different ship modules. Each event has a repair rating (I've seen as low as 7, but most are in the teens, some in the 20's) and if not repaired by the end of the turn each event will damage the ship or crew.

While an event is active, there may be effects on certain die rolls. Stasis freezes a die so it can't be rerolled, Injury does a point to the crew member and Void destroys the dice so they can't be used. For instance, if Stasis (1) and Injury (3) are listed, then any ones can't be rerolled and every three that is rolled causes a point of damage to the crew.

You stop the event by sending crew to the module, rolling their dice and spending them. If you put enough points into the repair to match it's rating then the event is repaired. Repairs carry over, so even partial repairs can help.

Also, each module has an ability that can be activated by using on or more dice (growing food, healing, reducing stress, etc).

It all sounds very cool. Sounds like there's lots of potential, but implementation is awful.

You have a limited number of Assists". Assists allow you to ignore Stasis
date: Injury and Void results. Here's the thing though
recommended: they are AUTOMATICALLY used. No decision making involved.  Even if you're fine with a die (or dice) locked by Stasis the Assist(s) get used.  Instead of giving you a limited resource you can use at the best moment
hoursPlayed:
you get a limited resource that's automatically used - so much for tactical decision making.

The totals needed for repairs are over the top compared to the total number of dice you can expect to roll.
The fifth turn (halfway point) added three events that required 64 repair (26
helpfulPercent: 14) and would do 7 damage (2
votesTotal: 3) to the ship which had 2 hull left. I still had 2 events going on - a 13 that caused -1 food
votesFunny:
and a 12 that was -1 die to all crew.

Surviving that situation isn't so much a matter of skill as luck.

reviewText:
The game is getting a bad rap because of it's difficulty. And those reviews are correct. The game is so difficult that it takes away the enjoyment of the game.

As an industry developer, I suggest making an easy mode or risk seeing your sales plummet. In it's current state, I cannot recommend this game.

There are plenty of excellent reviews, so please read those for the details.

reviewText:
Tharsis overall is a great concept for a game. In fact Tharsis is fun to play, for the first hour or two. However it leaves you with a feeling of frustration and contempt, after about 7 or 8 playthroughs. I dont mind the RNG and the randomness that comes from it at times, but I would like that randomness to play into the players favor once in awhile. For instance mabye not have everything break the very next turn after the player just repaired that section. Mabye provide ship up keep for sectors, allowing for the players to be proactive not always struggling. All in all, Tharsis has potential for a great game, however without some changes for alot of gamers who dont have the time to study stradegy on youtube vids and on the forums, how bout just making it easier for the common gamer. I know, the fanboys out there hate when people ask for it to be easier, I just think it would appeal to a much broader audiance. In closing if you want to be challanged to the point of frustration and anger, then by all means Tharsis is for you. When I bought the game I thought people complaining just had short attiention spans, and could'nt be bothered to figure it out. However, now I realize how true the  reviews were and hope other make smart choices. As of right now if I had to rate Tharsis on a scale of  1-10, it would come in at a 3.5 unfortunetly, or at least till the devs start listening to all the gamers and not just the fanboys and make the nessisary changes to make Tharsis the 7.5 or better game I feel it could be one day.


P.S I don't do reviews hardly at all, I mabye have done three ever in 8 years. So I appologize for any poor grammar or rambling. This was just one of those games that calls on you to relay your experience.


thanks,



OVERALL RATING- 3.5 OUT OF 10 would not recommend!!!

reviewText:
Nah. Video makes it look like it's a game full of challeging strategic choices, placed in a setting of a compelling narrative and story line.

It is none of that. It's a game based purely on the roll of dice and while you might eventually feel satisfied that you reach your goal (Mars) it would have been purely down to chance. Repeat the mission over and over again until the die rolls favours you; the choices you make only serve to give you the illusion of control.

It's a digital board game alright. But not a board game I would play; digital or otherwise.

reviewText: I've played XCOM through on ironman.  I've played the Long War mod through.  To the end.  I'm no stranger to the unlucky dice roll, but Tharsis really takes it to the next level, to the point where no amount of careful thought or meticulous analysis will save you from total disaster on most runs.  Extreme difficulty can be rewarding, but only when skill is the barrier.  When it's just a pile of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dice rolls it feels unfair and unfun.

reviewText: If you love playing craps while feasting on human flesh, you'll love Tharsis!  If you're remotely sane, however, stay away.  The game has some cool flavor, vaguely reminscent of The Martian, but the gameplay fails to live up to that expectation.  There's no more strategy than can be employed in craps or yahtzee.  The game designers presumably said Hey
date: roguelikes are popular.  Those are those games where the random number generator kills you over and over again
recommended: right?"  It's possible that there's some hidden depth to this that I haven't found
hoursPlayed: but it seems unlikely.  For a similar experience that DOESN'T feel like it's cheating you
voteText: go play FTL instead."

reviewText: Yeah, I get this game is hard and sometimes seems random. I don't mind. I knew it before I bought it. Sometimes you lose because you needed one point more than you rolled to repair that one damage. Or because the void has sucked out four of five die. ♥♥♥♥ happens.\n\nWhat I feel shouldn't happen is the game crashing to desktop in those rare moments everything goes fine. Tharsis, unfortunately, is as shoddy as the spaceship the unfortunate crew has to repair. Graphics, for example, is nothing to write home about - but judging from the framerate, it strained my GPU like Witcher 2 in high details would. Stability is something you could expect from an early beta. Subtitles in cutscenes between the missions are out of sync with the narrator's speech. Balance of in-game choices and damage is questionable. This game needed more polish before having been released.

reviewText:
the rng rage is real. You've never known true frustration until you've played this game, when all hope is hinged on 5 dice needing to roll a total number of 6 and you get all ones.

The rng plays a big part in the game but tactics and strategy are no less important for when you need to make due with bad rolls or imposible sittuations using module abilities, research, and crew abilities.

I played through about 40 games over 4 hours before I beat it on normal dificulty.

There is plenty of replay value for the price and it seems they're going to release more free content or dlc down the road.

You'll probablly end up rage quiting more than once but the game keeps you comming back for more until you finally manage to make it all the way to mars.

reviewText:
Tharsis is like Yahtzee in space. With a cool soundtrack. And neat short cinematics.

I like playing Yahtzee, and I like space.

Do not go into Tharsis expecting a high budget Mars exploration simulator. It's nothing more than a simple virtual board game.

If you know exactly what you're getting into, then maybe you'll enjoy the ride!

reviewText: This game is hard as hell and you're at the mercy of a random number generator, which is why I think some people don't like it. I personally really like it.\nIt's a unique concept, it's refreshing and it's just challenging enough to be fun.\nHowever, if you don't like games more to do with luck than skill, I'd recommend you don't buy it.

reviewText: I have to say, this game is rather enjoyable. I origianally had my doubts due to the number of negative reviews of the game and their statements are valid to a certain extent. The game is heavily lucked based but you already knew that by the description of the game. It's a dice based game. You expect luck to be a huge factor. However, those luck issues can generally be negated by strategizing when and where to properly re-roll and the like. I won on my first try and therefore, I am led to doubt these people that say they haven't been able to win over more than 10 tries. While that my be true and I just got extremely lucky i have no clue.\n\nAll this aside. I highly recomend this game for those who enjoy games based on luck mixed with strategy (I.E. Risk, FTL). The music is great. The concept is great. The only downside is that the game is extremely short. That may change in future updates with missions and all but at the moment the game is already great.

reviewText:
I like rogelike games, And have played a few of the. But this game takes roguelike to a obtuse level. I love a few of the rogueliek games that have recently came out like Darkest dungeon, and Risk of Rain.

Each roguelike game seams to have a nitch it fits in, this one is no different. Tharsis's nitch tho would be unplayable. Im all for a difficult game but even on normal i have yet to finish the game once in twenty playthru's.

I love the dice element and that it pushes you to make decisions or die, but the fact you stand no chance of completeing the game no matter what you do is beyond gameing and into self mutilation.

I want to like this game but i just cant recomend it to anyone.

Unless you like loosing do not buy this game. Because you will lose.... and lose...... and lose again.

reviewText: A very challenging game, but refreshing and full of very tough decisions. If you enjoy board games and are the type of person to not give up and get angry, this is the game for you. Took at least 20 tries before I got to mars, you learn how to better use your crew and your development cards better over time.\n\nIt's a shame this game was bombarded with negative reviews by people who only tried the game for less than 2 hours and immediately decided it was impossible. I assure you the game is not impossible, and once you get the hang of it, it can be beaten fairly consistently, but I have yet to tackle hard mode.

reviewText:
Unbalanced. To the point of the game not being fun....at first. But call me a sucker for punishment.

The balance issues are so glaring that it removes most of the strategy in the game due to it simply being impossible to get much further than week 5 (turn 5) even with near perfect play. This said, I do love games like Out There" and "FTL". (EDIT: I found a recent way around this issue by massively exploiting the FOOD pod to keep all crew at 4-5 dice the entire game. This makes it MUCH MUCH MUCH easier.)

This game is amazing in concept and I believe will be awesome once this is fixed
recommended: I'd estimate games have a 5% or less win rate. However this is hard to gauge as I haven't won one yet. It's also possible that this is because maybe you can get super ♥♥♥♥ed by turn 2 if things go badly. Perhaps if the games were longer or showed progression on a map similar to those games. I would like it if maybe there was some sort of path choices on progressing to Mars other than simply impacting the crew / ship via random bad or worse card draws.\n\nI'll keep at it and I'm sure the dev will fix any balance issues. When they do it will become a lot more fun. There is a difference between punishingly difficult and statistically impossible. The events are WAY WAY too OP in the current state. Hell
hoursPlayed: even just add an "EASY" mode.\n\nOther than that

reviewText:
I've really enjoyed this game so far.  It's really well made:
The systems and mechanics are interesting and fit well with the atmosphere.
The visuals are perfect for the style and add a lt to the tension.
It's very challenging - there are a lot of tough calls but I find myself getting better.

There seems to be a lot of people commenting about the randomness in a negative manner.  To me the game feels like a playing a board game - it strongly reminds me of Red November and perhaps Battlestar Galactica TBG.  There a lot of luck involved but it's all presented very clearly giving you the ability to plan your strategy based around the chance of failure. It's very possible to get a string of bad/good luck but that's just how things work with dice games.

I'd say if you like board games, suicide missions or atmospheric dice games - give it a try (just don't rage when if your mechanic fails to repair the hull at the worst possible time... sigh)

reviewText: While any game involving dice rolls is RNG bound, I think this game is able to balance out the RNG really well with the game mechanics, thereby in most cases if you do utilize your dice rolls efficiently amongst the different bonuses you get from each character, each room, and the research cards, and priotizing certain stats (ie ship health, crew health/stress/# of dice) each round, I feel like you are able to get some control on things even if the RNG fraks you over for it to be really fun.\n\nI really enjoy the mechanics, but do wonder if the game has longevity given the content thus far, so definitely looking forward to seeing what missions will bring to the game in the future!

reviewText:
TL;DR - It's a very good quick-playing game for one player. It can be an ideal small-game to play on the train or when you're a bit tired and don't feel like playing something larger. The music rules.

--

I am a board gamer (dice count) and this is the first video game that really gives me the kind of joy that I get from my board games.

This game nails dice rolling and that press-your-luck gameplay.

This game is procedural, it's not rogue-like as others have suggested. Rogue-likes (using the common definition) offer a variety of gameplay by altering traits during each play.

Where Dungeon of the Endless provides different technology upgrades and FTL provides different story moments; Tharsis provides random damage to random ship modules. The way it's executed certainly works. If you have to feed 23 die pips into repair and you're rolling 5 dice with an expected value of 17.5 with 2 re-rolls available it feels very possible. But, when a die with a roll of 3, 4, or 6 instantly disappears; it's time for a new tactic.

I enjoy unlocking more crew members, that gave me something to strive for.

This game is very good. If they find a way to vary the playthroughs a bit more than sometimes a lot of really hard to beat damage will occur" and "sometimes not so hard damage occurs" then it could be great.

At least for table gaming enthusiasts who don't mind fighting a losing battle; this should be on your list."

reviewText:
First off, this game has very little replay value in terms of story. Every run has the same exact story, in the same exact order, at the same exact times. Expect to skip many of the cutscenes once you watch them the first time.

It's a very simple game: roll dice and hope to not get RNG'ed to death. But each character has a specific ability that you can use, and each module has another specific ability that you can use. Yes, you may get RNG'ed to death, BUT you still have to use each character to the best of their abilities, and synchronizing abilities with the order you use the characters adds a bit of strategy to the game.

This game is reminiscent of gambling in how you play it, so in my opinion replayability is pretty high. No, you don't have anywhere near a good chance at beating the game, but an entire game can take about 15-20 minutes depending on how long you spend making decisions and how far you get. It's a great time killer if you need a short diversion, and if you need to there is a sort of save feature so that you can quit out and continue later.

I would recommend this game to people that enjoy board games or if you need a short game to play between activities. Personally, I really like this game and hope that the developers release more content for it, especially story-wise. This game is NOT for strictly-strategy oriented gamers or people looking for a story, as there is a greater emphasis on the RNG aspect of the game rather than the strategy and the story can be summed up in a few sentences. Also, there are no actual upgrades either in a run or with unlocks, but there are some unlockable characters that you can use in place of the original four. I'm not absolutely sure about this last bit, but I think that the voice actor also changes depending on which characters you choose, though the story doesn't change.

If the developers add in more story this game could definitely turn into one of my favorite games because I like the gameplay and how quickly the runs end (mostly in a flaming ball of failure, but hey that's how my FTL runs work too).

A few extra issues I have with the game:
-The skip cutscene button is space instead of the mouse button or any key, which is slightly annoying in a game which only uses the mouse other than skipping cutscenes
-No option to turn off the hints, and they return every run
-The unlock requirements are a bit ridiculous, as I have beaten the game and it will probably take me another hour or more of gameplay to unlock even one more character
-No option to undo any dice allocations (Chess rules: move is not set until you take your hand off the mouse button)
-What the heck does stress do? I still have no clue.

reviewText: There's hard, and then there's just plain unwinnable.   I wish I could recommend this, as there's a seed of a good game here.  But as it is, strategy doesn't matter enough, and the hits are too hard.  Even if you do everything right, success is pure luck.    I wish the devs good luck, but for now, I'm requesting a refund.  If you want a space-roguelike that hits the luck/strategy balance more effectively, check out FTL.

reviewText:
The game is pure RNG. There is no strategy involved at all.
Yes, you can try to manage the risks, but in the end, it is completly random if you get a run you can win.

The game presents you with a bunch of emergency situations you have to fix by rolling d6. The number of dice you have on each crew member depends on events from the previous round and some other factors.

You can choose which problems you want to tackle with which character, but each crew member can only take on one problem at a time. And there lies the problem: The amount and difficulty of emergencies is random.

Even if you would roll the best results on each dice roll, it is entirely possible, and very likely, to lose the game, just because you get more situations than you can solve.

If you see this as a challange and enjoy trying the same thing over and over again, this game is for you.


The graphics are nice and so are the sounds and music. The story is decent, but nothing special. Overall, the game has a good atmosphere and I like the grim scifi theme.

I think I would enjoy it more if the RNG would be just a part of the gameplay and not the whole game.

reviewText: Short version: stay away.\nLong version:  I wish I could like this game.  It has everything that I normally enjoy with a simple turn based game and I could totaly see myself making a board game variant to play around a table at home with friends(it has a simalar feel to games like pandemic) as this is essentially a board game.  The problem is that your ability to win or lose is essentially random, there is almost nothing you can do to prevent your death if its coming.  The reason for this is the game is random, and by random I mean everything(with one important exception) is random and therefore there is nothing that you can do to get on a firm ground.  Take FTL for example of how this is done right.  Nearly everything you encounter in that game has a counter be it diplomacy, having the right crew member, or just jumping away.  Sure you can get in a hopeless situation, but often it is of your own making.  In Tharsis you can be on top of the world one turn before only to end the next watching the ship fall apart due to situations you had no way to counter.  There is no risk reward" mechanic that FTL and Pandemic give you
date: there is only the hard random rolls of the computer in deciding if you are going to be allowed to advance or not.  Its sad because it feels like this game is almost there but is missing a component to allow you some agency in the game
recommended: but alas it falls short by inches (just like nearly everyone playing this game will in reaching mars)."

reviewText:
Its a good looking, easy to learn survival game with a strong theme. But that's all it has. You can be 5 days in, no situations, good food supply, high health, low stress and a well maintained ship. Day 6 starts with 3 situations, more damage potential than your ship has hit points and events which require 6 research points to prevent your crew dying on basic rolls.

This wouldn't be too bad, but there is a lot of this before you unlock any additional characters. So you grind and grind to unlock things that let you grind more. There is no real sense of accomplishment in this process either. Most turns you either got there because you had dice to spare or you lucked out. In other roguelikes, particularly the similar space themed FTL, it gives you an unlock for even getting half way through a campaign. Not here. You have to stick with the grind, learning very little about situation management along the way aside from tips that are not hard to work out yourself.

The worst part are the events. They're almost totally random. This would be ok if you maybe had a maximum of 2 events per turn. Usually you get 2-3, and require dice rolls totalling around 50 to complete them all. If you beat half that total, expect 30 on the next turn and so on. The feedback loop means that if you make a mistake, any mistake at all, its game over. If you do well, chances are its not going to matter. The research system seems to be the mitigating factor, athough you often require banking 4-6 specific dice in order to use these power-ups. Imagine playing a game like Left 4 Dead without the AI director. Just endless hordes of zombies to bash you until you die, and if you do get a MedKit, why not throw in a tank into the mix? My point is if the events were less random, and just showed a glimmer of hope for completing a day, the system would be less frustrating. Instead once the game decides to shut you down it just does it, no matter how well you've done up until that point.

There are more strategies available for beating the game when you have more characters available as synergy is clearly part of how to use the crew effectively. Using the Captain or Medic to provide small boosts to the team work well if the team is grouped together. Over the course of the game this can lose effectiveness as these crew work better when the group is at full size. But this is the part of the game that holds most weight in the strategy elements of the game.

The dice rolling aspect is a nice feature. Out of a potential 30 points, crew members can score an average of 17-18 points when fully functional. Penalties on these dice are strong. One prevents you re-rolling the dice, another removes the dice entirely and the third deals damage to your character. These penalties can vary in frequency and strength. One may remove a dice on any of three numbers. One can deal 3/6 damage to a crew member on a given number on a single dice roll. These can only be mitigated by preparation, and that preparation means you must sacrifice rolls earlier in the game. It adds a lot of frustration to the game, especially since the easiest difficulty still requires these large costs for single use effects.

Many players have proven the game is beatable, and beatable by method. This shows that despite the randomness of the game there is a layer of depth and strategy in there. It just requires a good grind to get there and that just isn't fun. With each playthrough I don't look forward to getting a little bit further every time, because that isn't how the game works. It isn't designed to be fair, its designed to make you feel hopeless and it works.

Will I play the game more? Yes I will. Is it beatable? Yes it is. Is this for everyone? No, its not. That said, a small amount of tweaking could make the decisions in the game more meaningful, more rewarding and/or less punishing when you do well. It doesn't need much, but the bit that is wrong is just holding the game back from a recommendation. Its not completely unfinished (though not all of the content is in the game yet) but it needs some attention, especially in the events department. Going from winning to game lost in a turn is not fun, needlessly sadistic and far too common. But if you like that kind of thing then this is your game. Otherwise, stick to FTL.

* Post Review Edit * After beating the game on Normal I realise just how important it is to get a lucky break just to start the level on good terms. Some runs are just fubar from the start while others can help well with the first few days. Having the right event in the right room can carry you through the game, and its about forcing these events to remain open. However, getting these events in the first place is luck of the draw, but the longer you get through the campaign, the more likely it becomes. It didn't feel like an achievement to beat this one. I also had to use the synergies of the other characters to beat it. The Doctor and Mechanic just can't cut it, especially with their abilities being so weak. In all my review isn't really affected by the end game. It just reinforces the point the game needs attention.

reviewText:
Short game, ultimately too easy on Easy, and not enough replayability to keep you interested for more than an hour or two. The game is good while it lasts, but I'd pick it up on sale.

Those who complain about it being RNG based - welcome to the genre. Playing smart *does* result in more wins than losses. You just have to strategize correctly. Took me a few YASDs, but I'm a veteran of hard-core roguelikes. 'Die and learn' is the order of the day. After a few failures, I figured out the best way to play the odds to capitalize on favorable odds, and minimize the bad rolls as much as possible.

Does it give you a giant middle-finger despite perfect play sometimes? Yep. It's part of dice games. It happens. Put on your big boy/girl pants and either deal with it or move on, but the game is balanced correctly.

reviewText:
Gameplay video + Review below:

https://youtu.be/8GzYTr9lsdo

I was sent Tharsis slightly before launch by the developer.
I actually love this game a lot more than I expected too. The dice mechanics can be frustrating but ultimately when you do manage to survive just one more day it's a pretty great feeling.
Have snippets of story between each turn really make it more interesting and impactful I found.
I love the risk reward element to the game. Managing stress levels and food. Deciding when is best to ignore events and when you are backed into a corner and have no choice but to pray for a 6 roll on a single die.
The game seems to me simple from the outset but has a massive amount of depth for you to understand if you want to minimise your risk. I keep coming back for more and it beats the hell out of me everytime.

reviewText:
Good game overall.
Good visuals, while not so original still have a charm of their own, simple yet efficient Art Direction.
The ambiance is there, you really feel like those 4 poor souls are floating in the void, and Weval's tracks  are a delight for the ears on top of greatly enhancing the feeling.
UI is top notch, very user friendly, no miss click to be wary of, everything you have to do slides smoothly and intuitively, with sober but efficient sound FX.

Game design is a mix of briliance with a handful flaws.
If you're used to RNG heavy games, then you know better than to face them head on, and that the importance lies in mitigating lesser harm while prioritizing long term survival and urgent matters over exhausting yourself against anything bad thrown at you.
To do so, you will have many different resources at your disposal, and this is where Tharsis shines, this is where you will take great pleasure managing growth, expense, individual bonuses and status, protection, etc, and how they cleverly intertwine with each other.

Unfortunately, you're still at the mercy of a couple bad RNG rolls which can ruin an entire playthrough in a matter of seconds. I personally find the devs could have implemented another thin layer of temporary bonuses when the player succeeds in repairing a room
First, in order to mitigate the fact that fixing a dangerous equipment failure can perfectly give an even worst failure the very next turn, which sometimes entirely defeats the purpose and puts you in an insoluble dire situation.
Second, to add more meaning into the strategic management of resources vs the different bonuses each room provides. As of now for the latter it's more often than not a case of up for grabs because there was an equipment failure here and you had a lucky spare die lying there. Not always though, you still have to know when to capitalize on selected room bonus which will make the difference, even when there's no incident there.
Transitional events (in between each weeks) could use some tweaking too, because even when your entire crew is at zero/very low stress you may still get a bad roll which will put an end to your smile.

Anyways, don't let that repel you from experiencing what great mechanics and artistic designs this game has to offer, because in the end reaching your objective is really not the most interesting part of the game, which is being challenged by impossible odds aboard a collapsing skiff in the middle of the void.

reviewText: Tharsis is a well made game, for sure. I like boardgames, and it plays like a boardgame. But is it fun? I'm not sure yet. Manageing various catastrophies which mount faster than you can deal with them gives the player very little sense of accomplishment or victory. Struggling to keep your head above water is just slow drowning. On top of that, the opaque way dice are used only serves to reinforce your helplessness. There is strategy to be found and utilized, but only as a means to mitigate the RNG punishment. Cool idea, underwhelming mechanics. Plus, it is set entirely on a single space station, no there is no exploration or discovery in the game as far as I can tell. I recommend it for people that are fine with games that rely heavily on RNG, like the enjoyable Armello, or the unenjoyable Chaos Reborn.

reviewText: A challenging dice game with a healthy dose of cannibalism. My playthroughs so far have been brutal, yet enjoyable. Tharsis plays much like a board game, and the replayability is helped by the randomness of the events and the unlockable crew you can take on future missions. While luck is certainly a factor, I think understanding of the crew and pod-specific skills is paramount to success. There are unavoidably bad rounds to be sure, but strategy is key, even when luck fails you - worst comes to worst you can still try to accomplish the goals to unlock more crew.\n\nThe game is story-light, which is fine for what it is. I definitely recommend it for those looking for a light dice-game that can be played in short sessions.

reviewText:
Like many, I wanted to like this game, and because it is hard.  I understand hard, having enjoyed Dark Souls, etc.  I also understand table-top games and dice-driven games, and it's more a random chance game.  What this game missed for me was more opportunity for an element of strategy...something closer to FLT.  I also give a nod to those that got exactly what they want, and beat it (even regularly).

There are so many chances to reduce stress, produce food and research, etc, but play after play I was just chasing down immanent disaster.  I wanted to find something that had even the slightest management planning, but like laundry, it just piled up again at the beginning of the next round, and nothing was ever solved.  A single death or badly-random damage round, and you knew the game was done.  It reminded me of bowling, where the minute you let go of the ball badly, you know you're screwed.

If a future patch could help with this, I would instantly repurchase.  I believe just the most modest tweaks would be enough.  One extra crew member, a half round" where you could implement some pre-planning or long-term strategy would be enough.  Now it feels like a Groundhog Day of a NASA shuttle disaster (either one)
date: and you can only watch it unfold."

reviewText:
I'll start with the positive; I like the overall premise that was 'borrowed' from stories like Blackhawk Down where you have the feeling of OBE (Overcome By Events.)  I really like the art, mood music and hard science that appears to be behind a lot of your decisions.  The game really does force you to understand the interplay between ship, health, current and future disasters, stress, and available resources.

Where it falls down is that that randomness almost always trumps any amount of strategic planning, careful dice hoarding or good choices.  I have played a number of times, altered my approach, and almost always come upon a turn where the number of 'points' I need to survive was just not mathematically possible even if I always rolled sixes.  Even if I had known when the disasters were going to occur and where, I still could not have prevented them.  I think the framework for fun is in place, but the odds are just so harsh and arbitrary.

Perhaps this harsh reality is truly reflective of actual conditions in space.  But, if I'm playing a game I would like to feel that I can have some amount of influence, and that I'm going to eventually get closer to winning.  Unfortunately with Tharsis I feel like I'm at a Space Craps Table.  With Cannibalism.

reviewText:
First!

You gotta be in it to win it

***Edit:

Had a chance to try it out now, a bit harsh since it is day 1 but unfortunately I feel it is not for me and is also not worth the price. While the game is mainly bug free (2 crashes, closed straight to desktop), it seems to lack content. Might have been influenced to make this purchase after watching 'The Martian'.

Don't get the 'challenge' part either, it's not that hard. With a bit of luck and a few re-rolls you can finish the game in under 30 mins.

Review
TL;DR: Game is lacks 'fun' right now (12/01/16).

Gameplay:
- Fun... for maybe 20 mins. Starts going downhill fast from there.
- Game is like a dice rolling simulator, given the correct conditions there is no real way to mess up. You just roll until your starting conditions are right and head straight to victory. Replay would be the same thing over and over, 1 run is maybe 20 mins long. No real incentive to repeat unless you really like rolling dice.
- Couldn't care less for the crew members, if one or more die, go back to menu screen and re-roll. Playthrough isn't actually long enough for you to care about the crew or to stop you from starting over.

Content / Features:
This is where the game falls short:

- Cannablism is never really needed, it feels like its there for lulz. If you ever needed to cannablize a crew member your ship is doomed already.
- Ship never changes structure, stays the same.
- Scenarios, whatever they are, are TBA.
- Story is soso, just says to rinse and repeat. Tried to create mystery but wasn't engaging. Not going to hang around to find out what supernatural forces are behind the cube.

Conclusion:
Cannot recommend this game in its current state and price, which is unfortunate since I had this on my wishlist since it was announced. While the graphics are slightly better than other micromanagement games like FTL and Endless Dungeon, Tharsis seems to offer far less value for money at this point. Lacks content would could have made it engaging and fails to provide an incentive to replay. Would have been more accurate to describe its current condition as 'Space dice rolling game. With some turn based mechanics. And a dash of cannibalism for good measure.'

Might have expected something like this from an Early Access game, not a finished product. Hope developers find a way to improve on this in the future.

reviewText:
I'm not trying to sound racist, what 3rd world country built this space ship? So much faulty compartments every turn, and the crews..... might as well replace them with space monkeys; they are so uneducated and incapable to complete their task. As a result, ship goes BOOM! Expect to lose a lot because this game's difficulty level is out of this world.

I can honestly recommend this game to anyone who would enjoy a challenging board game with great patience. If you are quick to anger, you might find yourself raging at the RNG elements. Even if you are making all your decisions with an absolute rational and logical mindset, the RNG element of the game will easily devastate all your hard works in one turn. Therefore, the unexpected events can be charming to some people because there is no guarantee to win on every play through.

The intention of this game tries to compare itself to D&D or other dice board games. D&D itself has a lot of RNG elements, but it's less frustrating because you are playing with your friends so there are a lot of social interactions during each play through. But this game puts you under pressure and stimulating what it's like to solve problems by yourself while staying calm.

Overall, the game's management system is complex enough with replay values. I enjoy it, but this is not a game for everyone.

reviewText: Fantastic game - great concept and execution. Totally addictive. This would make a superb board game.\nMy only criticism - BRUTAL !!!! I love playing challenging games and losing spectacularly is often more fun than winning, but, this game is too overwhelming too soon. A lower challenge level would be welcome - maybe one more crew member or a few less events. That way you can repair your shattered ego again before embarking on the normal" difficulty once more.\nOther than that - worth every penny (he says sobbing!)"

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The most fun I've had with a new game in a long time.

I'm not good at reviews. This game's pretty damn cool though alright? The soundtrack is excellent, as is the atmosphere, and I find myself really enjoying the solitaire board game style gameplay. It hasn't worn out its welcome for me; any defeat just feels like a learning experience. I've never felt shorthanded by the game's design or RNG when I lose.  For the record, my win percentage is currently hovering around 11%, ostensibly because I've been toying around with playing on Hard with random crew, combined with lots and lots of losses as I was just learning the game's intricasies.  Because there's so much open-endedness as to what you prioritise in your efforts to make it to Mars, I don't think any defeat can be blamed solely on RNG. When you get the hang of it, the game is actually surprisingly well-balanced. Defeat is more due to poor planning and lack of foresight than raw RNG, and it's a shame so many people have dismissed this game as one that just tries to be as hard as it can just for the sake of difficulty.

And there's something to be said about watching bloody dice roll around in low gravity at 60fps.

reviewText: TL;DR: Do your research, watch gameplay videos, adjust your difficulty expectations.  If  you lack patience, forethought, or basic math skills then skip this one. 5/10 just barely recommend.\n\nTharsis is a gamblers game at heart.   All you can do is know (or guess at) the odds and play them in your favour as best you can.  I strongly reccomend that you watch two let's play" before diving into this one
date: idealy one win and one horrible loss.  My tutorial playthough
recommended: which saw my entire crew dead then ship destroyed on the 4th turn
hoursPlayed: would have resulted in a refund request had I not researched and adjusted my expectations.  I see a lot of "It's like FTL"
voteText: and I don't know if I agree entirely.  FTL can go terribly wrong sometimes but I feel you usually have a fighting chance far more often than in Tharsis.  FTL has more variety in positive things/traits/weapons/crew overall and lasts much longer in terms of events and time with which to correct/soften mistakes and bad luck.  Tharsis leaves little room for error and bad luck so recovery is rarely an option and you can't get new crew like in FTL. In my 20 or so plays I've had 3 wins and they were all steamrolls.  I would expect. looking back and going forward

reviewText:
UPDATE: After several more hours, I have come to learn a bit more about how to play the game, which means my impression of it has changed. I do really like the ideas behind the game, and can now recommend it for folks who really want to stick out the learning curve. I have won only twice in all the hours I have played (14 hours at the time of this update), but now that I understand more how to play I have fun just trying to figure out how to go about taking on a round. It is also more fun now that I have more crewmen to choose from, not because any are particularly better than the others, but because it changes things up a bit.

I appreciate the dev's comment to this review, and think that a better tutorial or a learn to play mode" would really help improve the experience for a wider range of users.

One word of advice for new players: you might want to try to use the specialist to buy food in the early game and to get assists in mid to late game instead of having her work on events. Before I used her for this purpose she was more a liability than a help. After I started using her this way she became one of my core crew members.

Thanks to everybody who commented here. It helped me stick it out instead of abandoning the game.

=============================

reviewText:
UPDATED: They added a few missions that you can do in addition to the main story. I think this helps give it some extra replayability that it was missing before. In my opinion, it's well worth the $15.

The game was very fun, I enjoy games that require you to plan out multiple scenarios, sometimes risking it to survive, and sometimes losing it all.

The gameplay was pretty good, but I think the difficulty needs to be re-worked. I beat the game on the second try on easy, and then on my second try on hard. The game right now relies on an appropriate amount of RNG, so I think increasing the RNG to increase the difficulty would be a bad idea, so if there was a little more micro-managing to do or something, I think it would be better.

However, I think that despite the lack of depth, it is a good game. It may or may not be worth the $15 to you, as of now, I would say it is.
